qas.question: What year did Congress pass the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act?
What is Diethylene Glycol commonly used for now?
What was one of the things the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act do?
What drug killed over 100 people in 1937?
Diethylene glycol is mainly used today as what liquid?
What law did Congress pass following the Elixir Sulfanilamide incident?

answers.text: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of 1938

qas.question: The name "elixir" implied a solution in what liquid?
What year did Elixir pass the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act?
What is Elixir Glycol commonly used for now?
What was one of the things the Federal Food, Drug and Elixir Act did?

context: In 1937 over 100 people died after ingesting "<a0_0><a5_0><b10_0>Elixir Sulfanilamide<b10_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>" manufactured by <a1_0><a6_0><b11_0>S.E. Massengill Company<b11_0/><a1_0/> of Tennessee<a6_0/>. The product was formulated in diethylene glycol, a highly toxic solvent that is now widely used as <a3_0><a7_0><b13_0>antifreeze<b13_0/><a7_0/><a3_0/>. Under the laws extant at that time, prosecution of the manufacturer was possible only under the technicality that the product had been called an "elixir", which literally implied a solution in <a9_0>ethanol<a9_0/>. In response to this episode, the U.S. Congress passed the <a8_0>Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of <a2_0><b12_0>1938<b12_0/><a8_0/><a2_0/>, which for the first time required pre-market demonstration of safety before a drug could be sold, and <a4_0><b14_0>explicitly prohibited false therapeutic claims<b14_0/><a4_0/>.
